description: A San Francisco-based dating app called The League - which has been dubbed Tinder for people who are attractive or famous - is launching in London today.
title: Invite-only Tinder for beautiful people comes to London
title_page: Invite-only Tinder for beautiful people comes to London | Daily Mail Online
text:
The secretive dating app that's only for people who are rich, famous or attractive is coming to London.
Invitations to join the exclusive club, called The League, have been sent out to a chosen few of the most successful singletons in the city.
The selective dating service already has a waiting list of 10,000 people in the UK and the company has selected 2,000 'model users' to get things started.
Scroll down for video
Invitations to join the exclusive club, called The League, have been sent out to a chosen few of the most successful Tinder users in London, where it launches today
ARE YOU HOT ENOUGH? Founding members have to be between 24 and 36. The League will look at your degree, education institution, professional title (or past professions), industry and number of referrals. Before final admission, all applicants photos are reviewed and approved by the team (so you must be attractive as well). Ms Bradford says the app is for people who value 'ambition and intelligence above everything else'. The selective dating service already has a waiting list of 10,000 people in the UK. People can see if they pass the test by putting their phone number into their website.
Stanford graduate and The League CEO Amanda Bradford has been talking to single people in London over the last month to scout out potential users.
Glamorous parties have been hosted across the city at locations including Shoreditch House, The Ivy Chelsea Garden and the Chiltern Firehouse.
The League will be available on Android and iPhone from today.
Ms Bradford told Business Insider the first 'model users' have 'obviously spent time creating their profiles'.
Founding members have to be between 24 and 36 although this age range will expand as more people are selected to join.
'Referrals move a lot faster, we want to encourage our London users to bring their networks, so that it grows with the right user base,' Ms Bradford said.
Applicants were selected based on a variety of factors: degree, education institution, professional title (or past professions), industry and number of referrals from current members.
Before final admission, all applicants photos were reviewed and approved by the team - so beauty is an important asset.
CEO Amanda Bradford (second from the left) and her team have been talking to single people in London over the last month to scout out potential users in London
Invitations to join the exclusive club, called The League, have been sent out to a chosen few of the most successful singletons in the city
Here is one of the adverts for the new app. Founding members will be given a complimentary lifetime membership worth $999 (£780) and for those who weren't selected, membership costs $179 (£140) a year
Ms Bradford says the app is for people who value 'ambition and intelligence above everything else'.
Founding members will be given a complimentary lifetime membership worth $999 (£780) and for those who weren't selected, membership costs $179 (£140) a year.
'Think of The League as a member's only club, but one with a killer singles scene', said Ms Bradford.
'We're a community for intelligent, ambitious and high ­achieving people that are looking for an equal partner'.
The League says its mission is to create 'power couples' and uses data from Facebook and LinkedIn to feed into its algorithm, pictured is an advert
The League says its mission is to create 'power couples' and uses data from Facebook and LinkedIn to feed into its algorithm.
The app first launched in the US in 2015 and is available in San Francisco, New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Washington D.C., and Boston.
'London has an incredible pool of ambitious, well-educated men and women that are looking for someone who shares their drive', said Ms Bradford.
'We do the scouting and the vetting, you do the matching and the petting,' The dating service wrote on its website.
The selective dating service already has a waiting list of 10,000 people in the UK and the company has selected 2,000 'model users' to get things started
The League will look at your degree, education institution, professional title (or past professions), industry and number of referrals
Tinder has launched a similar version of the selective app.
The services are intended for 'celebrities and people who do really well on Tinder,' according to a source who spoke to Tech Crunch.
It's not yet clear how the selection process works on Tinder Select, but all of the users to have been invited so far have been 'attractive' with relatively high public or social media profiles.
Tinder appears to choose the individual users it wants join the elite group, which has been operating under the radar for at least the past seven months.
The League has been contacted for comment.
Before final admission, all applicants photos are reviewed and approved by the team (so you must be attractive as well). Here is a picture of their exclusive London launch
